author:
Jeff Faraudo

jfaraudo@bayareanewsgroup.com
title: UCLA rolls past Cal
text:
Posted: 10/22/2015 09:36:24 PM PDT Updated: 10/22/2015 11:41:37 PM PDT BearTalk blog PASADENA -- A promising Cal football season took a sharp turn in the wrong direction Thursday night at the Rose Bowl. 
UCLA scored on all six of its first-half possessions, and the 20th-ranked Bears never recovered in a 40-24 loss that calls into question much of what was accomplished during a 5-0 start. 
Now 5-2 overall and 2-2 in Pac-12 play after consecutive losses in prime-time ESPN games, Cal was competitive 12 days earlier in a 30-24 road loss to unbeaten No. 3 Utah. The Bears never gave themselves a chance against the Bruins. 
But quarterback Jared Goff, who threw three touchdown passes, vowed things will be different starting a week from Saturday at home against USC. UCLA running back Paul Perkins, right, puts a stiff-arm on California cornerback Darius Allensworth during the first half of an NCAA college football game, Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015, in Pasadena, Calif. (AP Photo/Mark J. Terrill) ( Mark J. Terrill ) 
"We're not going to let this ruin our season," he said. "I promise you this: We're going to be a different team next week. It's going to be a lot better from here on." 
The Bears haven't beaten the Trojans since 2003, when Aaron Rodgers was their quarterback. 
"Our guys are hurt and not happy with the way we performed," Cal coach Sonny Dykes said. "We'll come back with a better sense of purpose, and we'll play well against USC." 
The question is why they didn't play better Thursday night after getting five extra days to prepare. 
UCLA (5-2, 2-2) was coming off consecutive losses, including a 21-point thrashing at the hands of Stanford a week earlier. But it was the Bruins who came out of the gate fast. Advertisement 
Freshman Josh Rosen threw three touchdown passes, two of them in the first half when Ka'imi Fairbairn also kicked four field goals, including a 60-yarder on the final play of the half for a 26-10 UCLA lead. 
"It was a frustrating game all across the board," Goff conceded. "We just started too slow. If we want to beat good teams like this, we've got to start faster." 
Hoping to secure its sixth victory to become bowl eligible and win in Southern California for the first time in six years, Cal was outplayed in every way. 
"We didn't protect Jared very well," said Dykes, whose quarterback was sacked five times. "We did not do a good job on first down -- didn't run the ball particularly well. That's putting a lot of pressure on our offensive line and quarterback." 
The Bears converted a field goal on the game's first series, then totaled just 29 yards and one first down on their next four possessions. 
The Bears' performance on defense -- where they have been much-improved this year -- was just as listless. Cal didn't force a UCLA punt until midway through the third quarter and didn't make the game-changing plays that have become a staple this season. 
The Bears entered the week leading the Pac-12 with 21 takeaways but didn't force a turnover until Griffin Piatt recovered a fumble by Soso Jamabo with 6:22 left in the game. Cal sacked Rosen just once. 
"We're better than we played today," linebacker Hardy Nickerson said. 
The whole thing left Dykes a bit mystified. 
"I thought our guys were fresh and excited to play, and clearly that wasn't the case," he said. 
UCLA piled up 357 yards and 21 first downs in the first half. The Bruins then got the ball first to start the second half and marched 80 yards before Rosen threw his third TD pass of the night, a 21-yarder to Devin Fuller that made it 33-10. 
Rosen finished 34 of 47 for a career-high 399 yards. 
Dykes called for Harry Adolphus to run on a fake punt play on fourth-and-10 from the Bears' 25, trailing 20-3 with six minutes left in the second quarter. The Australian rugby player was stopped well short of the first down, and the Bruins cashed in with a field goal. 
"Bad call on my part," Dykes said. "We had three to block one, and we didn't get it done." 
Cal had no turnovers against the Bruins after committing six at Utah. Goff, intercepted five times by the Utes, was 32 for 53 for 295 yards. His three touchdowns give him 73 for his career. 
Safety Stefan McClure left the game with a shoulder injury, and linebacker Michael Barton sprained a knee. Dykes did not know the severity of either injury. 
UCLA scored 40 points against Cal for the first time since 2005, when the Bruins won 47-40. For more on Cal sports, see the Bear Talk blog at ibabuzz.com/beartalk . Follow Jeff Faraudo on Twitter at twitter.com/Jeff Faraudo.
